SystemOutput:
CHIEF COMPLAINT

Fatigue, lightheadedness, and shortness of breath.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Brian is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for congestive heart failure and hypertension, who presents today for follow-up of his chronic problems. The patient reports feeling out of sorts, fatigued, and lightheaded for the past five weeks. He has been experiencing shortness of breath during exertion, such as when doing house projects. He also reports feeling bloated occasionally and having slight chest cramps that resolve within an hour. The patient has been taking his medications and monitoring his blood pressure at home. However, his diet has been off due to recent home renovations and eating out more frequently.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Cardiovascular: Endorses fatigue, lightheadedness, and shortness of breath with exertion. Endorses occasional bloating and chest cramps.
• Respiratory: Endorses a slight cough.
• Gastrointestinal: Denies nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Cardiovascular: Jugular venous distention to 8 cm. 3/6 systolic ejection murmur.
• Respiratory: Fine crackles at lung bases bilaterally.
• Extremities: 1+ pitting edema in lower extremities.

VITALS REVIEWED

• Blood Pressure: Within normal limits.
• Heart Rate: Within normal limits.
• Oxygenation: Within normal limits.

RESULTS

Chest x-ray: Fluid in lungs.
Echocardiogram (4 months ago): Pumping function reduced at 45%, mitral regurgitation.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Congestive heart failure:
   • Medical Reasoning: Patient is retaining fluid, as evidenced by physical exam findings and chest x-ray.
   • Medical Treatment: Increase Lasix to 80 mg once a day. Patient to weigh himself daily and report any significant weight gain or worsening symptoms.
   • Additional Testing: Order another echocardiogram.

2. Hypertension:
   • Medical Reasoning: Patient's blood pressure is well-managed at this time.
   • Medical Treatment: Continue with Lisinopril 20 mg daily. Patient to continue monitoring blood pressure at home and report any elevations through the patient portal.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right knee pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Ms. Thompson is a 43-year-old female who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of right knee pain. The onset of her pain began yesterday when she was on a ladder changing a light bulb and stumbled, twisting her right knee while trying to catch her fall. The patient locates her pain to the medial aspect of her right knee. She has been applying ice and taking ibuprofen, but it has not provided significant relief.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Atrial fibrillation.

MEDICATIONS

Digoxin.

SURGICAL HISTORY

Rhinoplasty.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Reports right knee pain and tenderness. Denies any other pain.

PHYSICAL EXAM

MSK: Examination of the right knee: Tenderness over the medial meniscus area. Pain with valgus stress. Normal sensation.

RESULTS

X-ray of the left knee: No fractures or dislocations. Mild fluid present.

ASSESSMENT

1. Acute medial meniscus sprain/strain of the right knee.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, I have had a discussion with the patient in regard to her current symptoms. I have explained to her that her x-rays did not reveal any signs of a fracture or dislocation. I have recommended that we treat the patient conservatively with a knee brace and crutches temporarily for the next couple of days. We will schedule a follow-up appointment in about a week, and if her condition does not improve, we will consider an MRI at that time. Additionally, I have prescribed the patient ibuprofen 800 mg every six hours with food for a two-week supply.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Lower back pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Logan is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for diabetes type 2, hypertension, and osteoarthritis, who presents today with lower back pain. The patient reports lifting heavy boxes too quickly on Saturday, which resulted in a popping sensation and pain in his lower back. He has experienced stiffness since then. He has tried Tylenol, ibuprofen, and Icy Hot for pain relief with minimal improvement. He reports tingling in the toes of his right foot, which resolved by Sunday afternoon.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Diabetes type 2, hypertension, osteoarthritis.

SOCIAL HISTORY

The patient reports taking several long weekends over the summer.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Reports lower back pain. Denies chest pain, nausea, vomiting, fever, or chills.
Neurological: Reports tingling in the toes of his right foot, which has resolved.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Cardiovascular: 2/6 systolic heart murmur.
Musculoskeletal: Pain to palpation of the lumbar spine, pain with flexion and extension of the back, negative straight leg raise.

ASSESSMENT

1. Lumbar strain
2. Diabetes type 2
3. Hypertension
4. Osteoarthritis

PLAN

1. Lumbar strain: Prescribe meloxicam 15 mg once a day, continue icing, avoid strenuous activity, and refer to physical therapy.
2. Diabetes type 2: Increase metformin to 1000 mg twice a day, repeat hemoglobin A1c in 6 months.
3. Hypertension: Increase lisinopril from 10 mg to 20 mg daily.
4. Osteoarthritis: Continue monitoring knee, no further workup needed at this time.

The patient states he understands and is in agreement with the plan. All questions were answered to the patient's satisfaction.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up as needed.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Annual exam.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Ralph is a 62-year-old male with a past medical history significant for depression, prior lobectomy, and hypertension, who presents for his annual exam. The patient reports managing his depression well with Prozac and has no recent incidents. He has been taking Norvasc for hypertension but admits to occasionally forgetting to take it on weekends. He experiences shortness of breath with exertion, particularly during humid weather, while running 4-5 miles daily. He also reports nasal congestion due to pollen.

PAST HISTORY

Medical
Depression.
Prior lobectomy.
Hypertension.

Medications
Prozac 20 mg daily.
Norvasc.

EXAMINATION

Blood pressure: 120/80.
Heart: Slight 2/6 systolic ejection murmur.
Lungs: Clear.
Lower extremity: No edema.
Sinuses: Pain to palpation.

RESULTS

EKG: Normal.
Chest X-ray: Normal.

ASSESSMENT

1. Depression - well-managed with Prozac.
2. Prior lobectomy - no current issues.
3. Hypertension - controlled with Norvasc.

PLAN

1. Depression: Continue Prozac 20 mg daily. Refill prescription.
2. Prior lobectomy: No further workup or follow-up with the surgeon needed.
3. Hypertension: Continue Norvasc. Order echocardiogram for murmur. Follow up with results through the patient portal.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will be contacted with echocardiogram results and routine blood work through the patient portal. Call the clinic with any questions or new symptoms.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right index finger pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Sharon Brooks is a 48-year-old female who presents to the clinic today for evaluation of right index finger pain. She reports that she was skiing over the weekend and while going over moguls, her finger got caught on a strap and bent back. The incident occurred on Sunday. She has tried applying ice and taking ibuprofen, but the pain persists. The pain is worse with movement.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

The patient reports a history of constipation and had her appendix removed at age 18.

MEDICATIONS

Miralax for constipation.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Reports right index finger pain.
Gastrointestinal: Reports constipation.

PHYSICAL EXAM

MSK: Tenderness over the distal phalanx of the right index finger. No tenderness over the proximal joint or metacarpophalangeal joint. Pain with flexion.

RESULTS
Imaging

X-ray of the right hand: No fractures identified.

ASSESSMENT

Right index finger contusion.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's clinical history, examination, and x-ray findings, I discussed the diagnosis and treatment plan with her. I recommended an aluminum foam splint for her right index finger and prescribed ibuprofen 600 mg every 6 hours for pain relief, to be taken for one week. I advised the patient to follow up with the clinic if her symptoms do not improve within a week.

The patient states she understands and is in agreement with the plan. All questions were answered to the patient's satisfaction.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up with the clinic if symptoms do not improve within a week.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Iron deficiency anemia.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Patient reports a history of anemia since age 13, hysterectomy in 1996, and recent fatigue, chills, and shortness of breath.

MEDICATIONS

Patient reports taking ferrous sulfate 25 mg twice daily and over-the-counter vitamin B12.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Reports fatigue, feverishness, and chills.
Respiratory: Reports shortness of breath and wheezing.
Neurological: Reports headaches and worsening anxiety and depression.

VITALS

Not provided.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Respiratory
- Auscultation of Lungs: Not provided.

Cardiovascular
- Auscultation of Heart: Not provided.

Gastrointestinal
- Examination of Abdomen: No tenderness to palpation.

RESULTS

Blood work from 01/20/20 revealed low hemoglobin, stable hematocrit, normal iron labs, and low ferritin.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Iron deficiency anemia.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient has a long-standing history of anemia and recent blood work confirmed low hemoglobin and ferritin levels.
- Patient Education and Counseling: Discussed the importance of taking iron pills with orange juice to improve absorption.
- Medical Treatment: Continue ferrous sulfate 25 mg twice daily with orange juice for the next 12 weeks. Recheck CBC, iron, ferritin, B12, and folate after 12 weeks. Referral to hematologist.

2. Gastrointestinal evaluation.
- Medical Reasoning: To assess for potential sources of anemia or GI bleed, an upper endoscopy and colonoscopy will be scheduled.
- Patient Education and Counseling: Discussed the procedures and provided instructions for bowel prep.
- Medical Treatment: Schedule upper endoscopy and colonoscopy. If inconclusive, consider capsule endoscopy.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Worsening headaches and incidental pituitary lesion.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Mr. Bruce Ward is a pleasant 52-year-old male presenting with worsening headaches over the past few months. He denies any history of headaches. His past clinical history is unremarkable. Workup for headaches was initiated with brain MRI and serology, where a pituitary lesion was incidentally discovered. The patient reports headaches located behind his eyes, described as a dull nagging ache. The onset was gradual, starting about three months ago and worsening over time. The headaches are worse in the morning and last a few hours at a time. The patient denies any other symptoms, such as feeling sick, fever, rashes, neck stiffness, numbness, weakness, or passing out. However, he reports recently bumping into door frames.

PAST HISTORY

Unremarkable.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Employed as a computer programmer. Married for 25 years. Non-smoker, non-drinker, and no recreational drug use.

ALLERGIES

None reported.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Neurological: Worsening headaches, incidental pituitary lesion.
• Ophthalmologic: Bitemporal hemianopia.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Constitutional: Alert, oriented to time, place, and person. Affect is appropriate and speech is fluent.

Neurological: Cranial nerve examination is grossly intact. No focal motor or sensory deficit in the upper or lower extremities.

Ophthalmologic: Visual acuity and eye movements are normal. Pupils are equal and reactive. Visual field testing reveals bitemporal hemianopia. Color vision is normal.

RESULTS

MRI of the brain with contrast from 3/4/21: Pituitary lesion with elevation and compression of the optic chiasm. Ventricles are normal in size and no other abnormalities noted.

ASSESSMENT

• Pituitary adenoma with optic chiasmal compression.

Mr. Bruce Ward is a pleasant 52-year-old male with a benign-appearing pituitary adenoma, incidentally discovered during workup for worsening headaches. He is symptomatic with clinical and radiographical evidence of optic chiasmal compression.

PLAN

1. Refer the patient to an eye doctor for a full exam and visual field test to map peripheral vision prior to surgery.
2. Schedule transsphenoidal surgery to excise and decompress the pituitary fossa.
3. Discuss risks and benefits of surgery with the patient.
4. Monitor post-surgery for improvement in vision and resolution of headaches.
5. Encourage the patient to call if any questions or concerns arise.

End of note.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Chest pain and difficulty swallowing (resolved).

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

The patient experienced chest pain and difficulty swallowing in early October 2020, which resolved after four days. She visited the ER during that time, and a normal cardiac workup was performed. The patient has not had any recurrence of symptoms since then.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Uterine fibroids, anemia, and gallbladder removal.

SOCIAL HISTORY

The patient was going through a stressful job transition during the time of her symptoms.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Cardiovascular: Denies any current chest pain.
Gastrointestinal: Denies abdominal pain, normal bowel movements. Mild tenderness to light palpation in the upper abdominal quadrants.
Neurological: Denies difficulty swallowing.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Abdomen: Mild tenderness to light palpation in the upper abdominal quadrants. No masses or organomegaly.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Possible etiologies: GERD, dyspepsia, esophagitis, musculoskeletal etiologies, and anxiety.
- Medical Reasoning: The patient's symptoms and history suggest a possible anxiety attack related to her job transition, with or without a contribution from musculoskeletal etiologies.

2. Plan: Discussed the option of EGD versus monitoring for symptoms. The patient elected to self-monitor her symptoms and will call with any reoccurrence or change.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Evaluation of kidney function in a patient with Smith-Magenis Syndrome.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

The patient is a 22-month-old female with Smith-Magenis Syndrome. She is a twin and was born at 34 weeks and 3 days gestation. She has a history of feeding difficulties, reflux, and developmental delays. She is currently in feeding therapy, occupational therapy, physical therapy, and will soon start speech therapy. The patient has seen multiple specialists, including a geneticist, who mentioned that individuals with this syndrome may have kidney anomalies. The patient's mother reports that she has normal wet diaper frequency (8-10 per day) and adequate fluid intake.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Gastrointestinal: History of reflux.
• Genitourinary: Normal wet diaper frequency.
• Neurological: Developmental delays.
• Musculoskeletal: Mild hypotonia of the lower extremities.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• General: Well-nourished female, slightly fussy when examined.
• Eyes: Small appearing.
• Musculoskeletal: Mild hypotonia of the lower extremities in her arms.
• Genitourinary: Normal external female genitalia.

ASSESSMENT

The patient is a 22-month-old female with Smith-Magenis Syndrome, presenting for evaluation of kidney function.

PLAN

1. Obtain a kidney ultrasound today to screen for congenital anomalies of the kidney and urinary tract.
2. If the ultrasound shows abnormalities, determine next steps and future follow-up.
3. If follow-up is needed, schedule it at the town center location, as the family lives in Dallas, Georgia.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right wrist pain and swelling after a fall.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Patient reports falling while carrying a laundry basket and attempting to catch herself with her right arm. The injury occurred yesterday morning. She has been experiencing severe pain (9/10) and swelling in her right wrist since the fall. She has tried ice, an ACE wrap, and ibuprofen for pain relief with minimal improvement.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

No significant medical history.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Denies sleep disturbance.
Cardiovascular: Denies chest pain.
Respiratory: Denies dyspnea.
Neurological: Reports mild tingling in fingers of the right hand.

VITALS

Blood Pressure: 140/70 mmHg
Temperature: 97.2 degrees F
Heart Rate: 80 bpm
Respiratory Rate: 20 breaths/min

PHYSICAL EXAM

General: Patient is in moderate distress due to pain.
Upper Extremities: Right wrist with obvious swelling, ecchymosis, and tenderness on palpation. Pain on flexion, extension, radial deviation, and ulnar deviation. Limited ability to make a fist. Bony crepitus noted.

RESULTS
Imaging

X-ray of the right wrist: Positive for a Colles' fracture.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Colles' fracture of the right wrist.
- Medical Treatment: Apply a brace to the right wrist. Schedule surgery for fracture fixation. Prescribe Ultram 50 mg every 6 hours for pain management.
- Patient Education and Counseling: Discuss the surgical plan and expected recovery timeline. Instruct the patient to attend physical therapy post-surgery for rehabilitation.
- Follow-up: Reassess the patient in one month to evaluate progress and discuss the possibility of going on vacation.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up in 1 month.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right knee pain evaluation.

MEDICAL HISTORY

The patient has a history of hypertension.

SURGICAL HISTORY

No previous knee surgeries.

MEDICATIONS

The patient currently utilizes Lisinopril 20 mg daily.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Cardiovascular: Denies chest pain or shortness of breath.
Musculoskeletal: Reports right knee pain and swelling.
Neurological: Denies numbness or tingling in the leg.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Neurological
- Orientation: Alert and oriented x3. Cranial nerves grossly intact. Normal gait.

Respiratory
- Auscultation of Lungs: No wheezes, rales.

Cardiovascular
- Auscultation of Heart: Regular rate and rhythm. 2/6 systolic ejection murmur.

Musculoskeletal
- Examination: Pain to palpation of the medial aspect of the right knee. Pain with flexion and extension. Edema and effusion present. No pain on the lateral aspect of the knee.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Right knee pain (MCL strain).
- Medical Reasoning: The patient experienced a fall and twisted the knee, causing pain and swelling.
- Patient Education and Counseling: We discussed treatment options today.
- Medical Treatment: Prescribe Ibuprofen 800 mg twice a day for pain and swelling. Provide a knee brace for support and recommend icing the knee for 20 minutes, 3-4 times a day.
- Additional Testing: X-ray of the right knee showed no fractures or bony abnormalities.

2. Hypertension.
- Medical Reasoning: The patient's blood pressure was 150/70 during the visit, and they have a history of hypertension.
- Patient Education and Counseling: We discussed the importance of diet and sodium intake in managing hypertension.
- Medical Treatment: Continue Lisinopril 20 mg daily.
- Additional Testing: Referral to nutrition for dietary counseling.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up in 2 weeks.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Left shoulder pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Wayne is a pleasant patient who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of left shoulder pain. The onset of his pain began approximately 3 weeks ago, and he cannot recall any specific injury. He has been active and recently working on renovating his basement. The patient reports difficulty reaching for objects, lifting objects, and reaching overhead due to pain. He has been taking two extra strength Tylenol every six to eight hours, which provides some relief but not complete relief.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient reports being active and working on a basement renovation project.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Reports left shoulder pain.
Neurological: Denies numbness or tingling in arms or hands.

PHYSICAL EXAM

MSK: Examination of the left shoulder reveals limited active and passive range of motion. Tenderness of the greater tuberosity of the humerus, but no tenderness at the sternoclavicular or acromioclavicular joints. Good hand grips.
Neurovascular: Capillary refill is less than three seconds, and sensation is intact to light touch in the left arm.

RESULTS

X-ray of the left shoulder reveals no fractures.

ASSESSMENT

Left shoulder rotator cuff tendinopathy.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, I have discussed with the patient that his symptoms are most likely due to a rotator cuff tendinopathy. I have ordered an MRI for the left shoulder to further evaluate the issue. I am referring the patient to physical therapy for approximately 6-8 weeks and advised him to continue taking Tylenol for pain relief. If symptoms do not improve, we will consider a steroid injection for the shoulder. The patient will follow up with me after completing physical therapy.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will receive educational materials on physical therapy and what to expect. He will schedule a follow-up visit with me after completing physical therapy.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Left knee pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Andrea is a pleasant patient who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of left knee pain. The onset of her pain is occasional, less than once a day, and occurs when walking. She reports that her knee "gives out" and she feels like she might fall, but usually catches herself. The pain is internal and involves the whole kneecap. She denies any specific injury or hearing/feeling a pop. The patient has not taken any medication for the pain as it does not last long. She is concerned about an upcoming trip with potential walking and line dancing, and is considering not participating in the dancing due to her knee pain.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient reports that she likes to travel.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Reports left knee pain.
Cardiovascular: Reports a slight 2/6 systolic ejection murmur at the left base.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Vital Signs: Temperature 98.2, Pulse 72, Respirations 16, Blood Pressure 122/70.
Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm, 2/6 systolic ejection murmur at the left base.
Respiratory: Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally.
MSK: Left knee exam reveals no ecchymosis, edema, effusion, or pain to palpation. No decreased range of motion. Negative varus and valgus test.

RESULTS

X-ray of the left knee reveals no evidence of fracture or bony abnormality.

ASSESSMENT

1. Left knee pain - likely arthritis.
2. Hypertension.
3. Diabetes mellitus.

PLAN

1. For left knee pain, prescribe meloxicam 15 mg daily and consider physical therapy to strengthen the muscles around the knee.
2. Continue lisinopril 20 mg daily for hypertension and order an echocardiogram to evaluate the heart murmur.
3. Order hemoglobin A1C and lipid panel to assess diabetes management and potential adjustments to metformin.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up with the results of the echocardiogram, hemoglobin A1C, and lipid panel. The patient is advised to be cautious during her upcoming trip and consider not participating in activities that may exacerbate her knee pain.

CC:

Follow-up during neo-adjuvant chemotherapy for stage three non-small cell lung cancer.

HPI:

Ms. Beverly is a 53-year-old female with a recent diagnosis of stage three non-small cell lung cancer. She presents for follow-up during neo-adjuvant chemotherapy. She was diagnosed with a 4.4 cm left upper lobe nodule, and biopsy was positive for adenocarcinoma. Molecular testing is pending at this time. She reports minimal cough, sore throat, and mild fatigue. No nausea, vomiting, or shortness of breath. She has good support from family, friends, and nursing staff.

EXAM:

Vitals are stable, and oxygen saturation is satisfactory. Neck exam shows no cervical or supraclavicular lymphadenopathy. Heart exam reveals regular rate and rhythm with no murmurs. Lung exam demonstrates bilateral crackles. Skin exam shows erythema on the anterior left side of the chest, likely related to radiation. Lower extremities show no edema.

RESULTS:

Chest X-ray reveals mild radiation pneumonitis.

IMPRESSION:

1. Stage three non-small cell lung cancer.
2. Radiation pneumonitis.
3. Painful swallowing.

PLAN:

1. Continue current chemotherapy regimen (cisplatin and etoposide) and radiation at 45 Gy. Repeat imaging after completion to assess tumor shrinkage for potential surgical removal.
2. Prescribe low-dose prednisone (40 mg daily for 5 days) to reduce inflammation from radiation pneumonitis.
3. Prescribe lidocaine swish and swallow (four times daily) to alleviate painful swallowing and promote adequate food and fluid intake.

The patient is agreeable to the plan and has no further questions at this time. Follow-up scheduled for the next visit.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Low immunoglobulin A level.

SOCIAL HISTORY

The patient has recently traveled to Zambia. Family owns a donut shop.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Respiratory: Denies frequent infections, but reports colds that linger in the wintertime.
Gastrointestinal: Denies frequent diarrhea or abdominal infections.
Family History: No known immune deficiencies in the family.

VITALS

No fever or concerning vitals noted.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm. No murmurs.
Respiratory: Lungs clear, no wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.
Neck: No lymphadenopathy.
Abdominal: Soft, non-tender.

LAB RESULTS

IgA deficiency confirmed in recent lab work.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. IgA deficiency.
- Medical Reasoning: Lab work confirms low IgA level, but the patient does not report frequent infections or other concerning symptoms.
- Patient Education and Counseling: Explained the nature of IgA deficiency and advised the patient to watch for infections that do not resolve or severe diarrhea.
- Medical Treatment: Will order additional blood work to check other antibodies. Instructed the patient to inform medical professionals of their IgA deficiency if they require blood products in the future.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right elbow pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Lawrence is a patient who presents to the clinic today for evaluation of right elbow pain. The patient reports that the pain began about four days ago and is located on the inside of the right elbow. He denies any history of trauma or previous injury to the elbow. The patient has been engaging in pottery activities during the pandemic, which he believes may have contributed to the pain. The pain is rated as a 6/10 in intensity and has been affecting his sleep and daily activities. He has tried ibuprofen for pain relief with minimal success.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Musculoskeletal: Endorses right elbow pain, radiating slightly into the forearm. Denies shoulder pain.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Vitals: Within normal limits.
• Musculoskeletal: Positive for pain to palpation at the medial epicondyle of the right elbow. Positive for pain with pronation of the forearm and resistance against flexion of the left wrist. No swelling or deformity noted.

RESULTS

X-ray of the right elbow: No fracture or bony abnormality detected.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Lawrence presents with right elbow pain, consistent with medial epicondylitis, likely due to overuse and potential damage to the tendons that bend the wrist towards the palm.

• Patient Education and Counseling: Instructed the patient to rest the affected elbow, avoid pottery activities for the next couple of weeks, and wear a sling while awake.
• Medical Treatment: Advised the patient to apply ice to the elbow for 20 minutes, three times a day, and take ibuprofen 600 mg q.6 h. with food for a full week.
• Follow-up: Scheduled a follow-up appointment in one week to assess the patient's progress.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Recent emergency department visit due to chest pain and shortness of breath.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

David is a patient with a history of hypertension who presents today for a follow-up after a recent emergency department visit. He reports experiencing chest pain and shortness of breath while walking outside, which led to his visit to the ER. He admits to not consistently taking his medications and not following a strict diet.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Cardiovascular: Endorses chest pain and shortness of breath.
• Respiratory: Denies any issues with sleeping.
• Gastrointestinal: Denies any issues.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Blood pressure: 128/72
• Neck: No jugular venous distention.
• Cardiovascular: 2/6 systolic ejection murmur, stable.
• Respiratory: Lungs clear bilaterally.
• Extremities: Trace edema in lower extremities.

RESULTS

Echocardiogram: Preserved ejection fraction of 55%, normal diastolic filling, mild to moderate mitral regurgitation.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

David is a patient with a history of hypertension who presents today for a follow-up after a recent emergency department visit due to chest pain and shortness of breath.

Congestive Heart Failure:
• Medical Reasoning: Likely caused by dietary indiscretion and uncontrolled hypertension.
• Medical Treatment: Continue bumex 2 mg once daily.
• Patient Education and Counseling: Consult to nutrition for dietary advice, weigh daily, and call if weight gain of 3 pounds in 2 days.

Hypertension:
• Medical Reasoning: Uncontrolled hypertension, inconsistent medication adherence.
• Medical Treatment: Continue cozaar 100 mg daily and norvasc 5 mg once daily.
• Additional Testing: Order renal artery ultrasound to rule out other causes.
• Patient Education and Counseling: Encourage consistent medication adherence and follow up with nutritionist for dietary advice.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right-sided abdominal pain below ribs.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Russell is a pleasant patient who presents to the clinic today for evaluation of right-sided abdominal pain below his ribs for the last several days. He reports the pain moves to his lower abdomen and into his groin. The pain is intermittent and severe when it occurs. He experiences difficulty finding a comfortable position during the pain episodes. The patient also reports burning sensation during urination and dark-colored urine. He has a history of kidney stones and a family history of kidney stones in his father.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Previous kidney stones.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Not provided.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Gastrointestinal: Reports right-sided abdominal pain and nausea. Denies vomiting.
Genitourinary: Reports burning sensation during urination and dark-colored urine.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Abdomen: No tenderness to palpation, no rebound or guarding, no peritoneal signs.
CVA: Positive tenderness on the right flank.

RESULTS
Imaging

CT scan of the abdomen: 0.5 cm kidney stone located in the proximal right ureter. No evidence of hydronephrosis.

ASSESSMENT

Acute nephrolithiasis (kidney stone).

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's clinical history and examination today, I have discussed the following treatment plan with the patient:
1. Encourage increased fluid intake to facilitate urination and stone passage.
2. Prescribe oxycodone 5 mg every 6-8 hours as needed for pain, alternating with Tylenol.
3. Provide a urine strainer for the patient to catch the stone when it passes.
4. Order a basic metabolic panel, urinalysis, and urine culture.
5. Schedule a follow-up appointment in 1-2 weeks to evaluate the patient's progress. If symptoms persist, discuss further treatment options such as lithotripsy or ureteroscopy.

The patient states he understands and is in agreement with the plan. All questions were answered to the patient's satisfaction.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up with me in 1-2 weeks.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Nonhealing diabetic foot ulcer on the right foot.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Patient reports having a foot ulcer for about six weeks, initially caused by tight shoes. The blister became unroofed with thick, soft, mushy skin and foul-smelling yellow drainage. Patient's wife noticed a red streak coming up the front part of the ankle along the inside portion of the calf muscle, which is hot to touch. Patient reports cramping in the calf muscle and has been experiencing a cough and shortness of breath for the past two days.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Diabetes mellitus with diabetic neuropathy. Patient's A1C is 6.7, and blood sugars have been trending in the 300-400 range for the past two weeks.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient enjoys hiking and recently hiked a new trail.

MEDICATIONS

Antibiotics (6 days into a 10-day course).

PHYSICAL EXAM

Vitals: Slight fever, otherwise stable.
Foot Exam: Necrotic wound on the heel, approximately 2x2 cm with sloughing tissue, cellulitis, and erythemia. No bony exposure. Non-palpable dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses, but present via Doppler.
Pain: Patient does not feel pain when the affected area is pressed.

RESULTS
Imaging

Right foot X-ray: No evidence of osteomyelitis.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Nonhealing diabetic foot ulcer.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient's history and physical exam findings are consistent with a nonhealing diabetic foot ulcer.
- Medical Treatment: Debridement in the office, culture, and potential change in antibiotic therapy depending on culture results. Monitor redness and swelling in the calf. Follow up in 7 days.

2. Diabetes management.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient's recent blood sugar trends and A1C indicate a need for closer monitoring and management.
- Patient Education and Counseling: Encourage the patient to follow up with their endocrinologist to maintain A1C below 7 and closely monitor blood sugars during antibiotic and potential other medication therapies.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will continue the current antibiotic course and follow up in 7 days. The patient is advised to follow up with their endocrinologist for diabetes management.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Tick bite and knee pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Richard is a patient with a history of hypertension and diabetes who presents with a tick bite on his right knee. The bite occurred over a week ago and has been causing burning and discomfort. He denies fever, chills, and joint pain other than his typical arthritic pain. He has not experienced difficulty moving his knee or walking. He has had tick bites in the past but has never been diagnosed with Lyme disease. Since the tick bite, he has been experiencing headaches and generally not feeling well.

Regarding his hypertension, he has been taking lisinopril and monitoring his blood pressure periodically, which seems to be under control. He denies any side effects from the medication.

Regarding his diabetes, he has been watching his sugar intake and taking metformin most of the time. He reports that his blood sugars have been running in the 120s.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• General: Endorses headaches and generally not feeling well since the tick bite.
• Musculoskeletal: Denies joint pain other than typical arthritic pain.
• Skin: Bull's-eye rash over the right knee.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Vital Signs: Blood pressure 122/70, heart rate 67, temperature 98.4.
• Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs, rubs, or gallops.
• Respiratory: Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally.
• Musculoskeletal: Full range of motion of the right knee, pain to palpation of the right anterior knee.
• Skin: Erythema, edema, and area of fluctuance over the right patella, bull's-eye rash over the right knee.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Tick bite and possible Lyme disease:
   • Medical Reasoning: Presence of a bull's-eye rash and symptoms since the tick bite raise concern for Lyme disease.
   • Additional Testing: Lyme titer and Western blot will be ordered.
   • Medical Treatment: Start doxycycline 100 mg twice a day for three weeks.
   • Patient Education and Counseling: Informed patient about the possibility of Lyme disease and the treatment plan.

2. Hypertension:
   • Medical Reasoning: Patient's blood pressure is well-controlled on lisinopril.
   • Additional Testing: Order lipid panel to assess cholesterol levels.
   • Medical Treatment: Continue lisinopril 20 mg daily.

3. Diabetes:
   • Medical Reasoning: Patient's blood sugars are running in the 120s, indicating good control.
   • Additional Testing: Order hemoglobin A1C and basic metabolic panel to assess long-term blood sugar control and kidney function.
   • Medical Treatment: Continue metformin 1000 mg twice a day.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.
